title: 0-Days + Hitlists torrentable (2012-04 - 2013-12)
description:
Lightly compressed archive of 444 (sic!) torrent metadata files for all Weeklies,
as well as a few Monthlies, posted during the stated period and via the accounts  <a href="
http://thepiratebay.se/user/shipJ" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW">
http://thepiratebay.se/user/shipJ</a>  and <a href=" http://thepiratebay.se/user/shipjolly" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW"> http://thepiratebay.se/user/shipjolly</a>  .

Not sure why anybody other than me would have a use for this, as the majority of these torrents are quite dead by now - but that's what I thought for a long time about the corresponding plaintext listing, and was gravely mistaken. So, here goes.

I drastically shortened and systematized the filenames, which now consist of four snippets (or "tokens", if you're into programmerese), separated by underscores.

[...]   7739852_2012.10.10_HL.03.R1_I-N.torrent
        7740406_2012.09.00_0D.01.R2_A-V.torrent   [...]

First snippet: TPB identifier of the torrent. I put this on the left to get them in chronological order, plus you can use it to construct the upload page URL directly.

Second snippet: Date (whodathunk) given in torrent name. Ordinary dates always refer to Weeklies, while dates with a "00" in the day position always refer to monthlies.

Third snippet: Type of torrent. In order, 0D(ay) or H(it)L(ist), part number, and
revision (1 for the regulars, 2 for "fixes", "repacks", "fillers", and so forth).

Fourth snippet: Initial letters of first and last files contained. Occasionally meaningless when torrent wasn't alphabetized, but quite useful otherwise, I'd say.

Any mistakes made in the original titles are preserved here, incidentally, so trust the first and last tokens rather than the ones in the middle, whenever in doubt. :)
